attributes.title: How do prescription drug monitoring programs influence clinical care among health professionals: A Systematic Review

q1.value: How do prescription drug monitoring programs influence clinical care among health professionals: A Systematic Review

q3.value:
There have been considerable increases in opioid prescribing, particularly in first world countries including America, Canada and Australia. This marked increase in prescription opioid use is associated with considerable related harms including morbidity, mortality, accidental overdose, use disorder and dependence. Dramatic increases in prescription opioid use in the past two decades have resulted in a global public health concern. As the majority of opioid related deaths in Australia are associated with prescription opioids, various public health approaches have been identified to address associated harms, one of which is the implementation of prescription drug monitoring programs.

Prescription drug monitoring programs are a clinical intervention that have been established and implemented widely in North America, Europe and Australia. They are an important public health initiative and are designed to allow those prescribing and dispensing prescription opioids to make more informed choices, aid decision making and facilitate earlier intervention where signs of higher-risk medicine use are emerging.

The implementation of such programs is associated with various changes in clinical practice amongst those using these programs. The current review is interested in the specific changes in clinical practice and behaviour at the individual/health professional level.

The primary research question is "How do prescription monitoring programs influence healthcare professional's clinical practice?"

q4.value: We hypothesize that implementation of prescription drug monitoring programs will influence clinical care in multiple ways including changes in prescribing practices or medication substitution (e.g. prescribing non monitored drugs), medication refusal, changes in communication (between healthcare professionals and patients/carers), increased awareness/ detection of misuse, counselling, screening for use disorder or dependence, referrals etc

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is a systematic review of how implementation of prescription drug monitoring programs influence clinical care and behaviour change amongst health professionals.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value: Registration submitted with Prospero on 29th November 2019, prior to running literature searches. Registration with OSF registries occurred prior to commencing data extraction.

question.value:
We have undertaken some initial literature reviews to determine the types of articles currently published and that are relevant to our systematic review. We have also reviewed the literature and searched Prospero to see if there are any similar reviews which have been published or are currently being undertaken.

For this systematic review, we intend to search a range of databases including MEDLINE, PubMed, CINAHL, Web of Science, Scopus, Embase in addition to searching the grey literature and checking the reference list of identified articles within our searches.

We intend to use search terms such as 'prescription drug monitoring program' or variations of this such as 'prescription monitoring', 'prescription monitoring program'. Our search will relate specifically to changes in clinical practice at the clinician/individual level that have resulted from the implementation of prescription drug monitoring.

No restrictions will be imposed with regards to year of publication or language.

Exposure variable: Use of a prescription drug monitoring program in a clinical setting.
Outcome variables: Changes in clinical practice following the use of a prescription drug monitoring program. Changes in health professional behaviour and clinical practice including changes in prescribing practices or medication substitution (e.g. prescribing non monitored drugs), medication refusal, changes in communication (between healthcare professionals and patients/carers), increased awareness/ detection of misuse, counselling, screening for use disorder or dependence, referrals etc

Two reviewers will independently examine the title and abstract of all identified articles from the searches, using Covidence software. Full text copies of relevant review articles will be obtained and two reviewers will then assess for inclusion and where excluded, document reasons for this. Inter-review discrepancies will be discussed, with the aim to reach a consensus on inclusion or exclusion, and an additional reviewer will also be consulted where a consensus is not reached.
Data will be extracted from identified articles using a detailed and structured template, which will be piloted with initial studies and refined where needed. Data extracted will include information pertaining to the type of article, when and where the study was conducted, study aims and objectives, participant population, sample size, inclusion and exclusion criteria, main study outcomes, changes in clinical practice etc

Findings will be qualitatively and quantitatively synthesized as appropriate and findings will be described qualitatively. We will attempt to quantitatively synthesize changes in prescribing, supply and other aspects of clinical practice where possible.

The National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) evidence hierarchy will be used to assess the quality of evidence. Study quality will be assessed by 2 independent reviews and discrepancies will be discussed with a third reviewer where needed.

q22.value:
Two reviewers will independently examine the title and abstract of all identified articles from the searches, using Covidence software. Full text copies of relevant review articles will be obtained and two reviewers will then assess for inclusion and where excluded, document reasons for this. Inter-review discrepancies will be discussed, with the aim to reach a consensus on inclusion or exclusion, and an additional reviewer will also be consulted where a consensus is not reached.
Data will be extracted from identified articles using a detailed and structured template, which will be piloted with initial studies and refined where needed. Data extracted will include information pertaining to the type of article, when and where the study was conducted, study aims and objectives, participant population, sample size, inclusion and exclusion criteria, main study outcomes, changes in clinical practice etc

attributes.title: The Construction of Trust in the State: Evidence from Police-Community Relations in Colombia

q1.value: The Construction of Trust in the State: Evidence from Police-Community Relations in Colombia

q2.value: Eric Arias | Rebecca Hanson | Dorothy Kronick | Tara Slough

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: Trust in government is the subject of “an industry of research” (Levi and Stoker, 2000) in political science, sociology, and economics. Since at least the 1960s, researchers have worked to define trust in government, to develop survey instruments that measure it, to pin down its determinants, and to understand its consequences, which include political and economic behaviors as fundamental as voting, obeying the law, or even buying goods. This large literature has produced robust findings. But most studies focus on trust in an abstract government or in national institutions like Congress; less is known about the causes or consequences of trust in specific, local government agents. Levi and Stoker (2000) argue that this type of trust—trust in particular authorities—is essential to understanding “everyday political behavior,” and they therefore “urge scholars to expand their inquiries beyond the traditional focus on citizens’ trust in ‘government’ in general” (p. 495–496). This study investigates the determinants and consequences of citizen trust in a specific, local government institution that performs an elemental function of the state: the police.

q16.value: We first propose a paper on the evolution of trust in the police. Second, we propose a paper on gender and demand for better policing. Finally, we will contribute to the Metaketa-IV analyses and joint product with a discussion of how the efficacy of these interventions can be compared, given the evidence. All products draw on data collected from: baseline and endline surveys of citizens; endline surveys of community police; intervention implementation records; administrative data on crime and population; ethnographic observation of community policing meetings; and qualitative focus groups and interviews.

q17.value: Field experiment on community policing in Medellin, Colombia. The experiment consists of two interventions, crossed in a 2x2 factorial design: the creation of beat-level community policing meetings and the dissemination of security-related information (on norms, procedures, and outcomes).

q19.value: Unit of randomization: 347 police-beats (cuadrantes). Baseline survey of 5,205 citizens. Expected endline of approx. 3,400 citizens and close to 700 police officers.

attributes.title: Effects of Genetic Endowments, Parents’ Socioeconomic Status, and Gene-Environment Interaction on Spouse Pairing Patterns in the United States

q1.value: Effects of Genetic Endowments, Parents’ Socioeconomic Status, and Gene-Environment Interaction on Spouse Pairing Patterns in the United States

q2.value: Fumiya Uchikoshi, Dalton Conley, Ramina Sotoudeh

q3.value: A nationally representative survey of testing implications on the gene-environment interactions hypothesis for spouse pairing patterns.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q9.value: N/A. We are not doing a randomized study.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: The current study uses the publicly available RAND HRS Longitudinal File 2016 (v.1) and Polygenic Score Data (PGS) (v.3.0). Contributors have not started analysis.

question.value: Data collection is already completed and respondents were drawn by Institute for Social Research, University of Michigan.

q13.value: Polygenic scores for educational attainment are available for respondents who provided salivary DNA between 2006 and 2008, which includes samples from the initial cohort (born 1931-1941) to early baby boomers (born 1948-1953). Saliva completion rates were 83% in 2006, 84% in 2008. Samples with both phenotypic and genotypic information are 15620.

q14.value: Data collection is already completed and respondents were drawn by Institute for Social Research, University of Michigan.

q25.value: We will further make our code public for reproducibility of research.

attributes.title: Community monitoring to facilitate climate change adaptation by local institutions in water-scarce regions of Central America

q1.value: Community monitoring to facilitate climate change adaptation by local institutions in water-scarce regions of Central America

q2.value: Francisco Alpízar | Maria Bernedo | Paul Ferraro

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: To better manage common pool resources, scholars and practitioners have recommended incorporating citizen monitoring into resource governance systems (Ostrom, 1990). Despite abundant case study evidence for these recommendations, empirical evidence for the impacts of community monitoring is scarce. Moreover, none of the existing studies were done in the context of natural resources. Whether citizen monitoring in the area of natural resources affects resource outcomes thus remains an open, empirical question. In our study we test the impact of community monitoring on the management of groundwater by community-based water management organizations (CBWMOs), which are the most important suppliers of water in rural areas of low and middle-income countries globally. To achieve this goal, we run a randomized controlled trial (RCT) with CBWMOs where we conduct public workshops to present the monitoring system and to recruit and train monitors. Monitors gather and report information using primarily a novel cellphone application called SIMA that distributes the information to CBWMO committee members and to the citizens in the respective community.

q16.value: We hypothesize that citizen monitoring and communication will reduce water pumped from aquifers and will improve water quality. Our theory develops four primary mechanisms through which citizen monitoring work: (1) enhanced supply of information to the management committee on the real-time conditions of the water supply, water infrastructure and water use; (2) enhanced scrutiny of the management committees’ activities and performance by citizens, (3) greater community interest about the water system and its management performance, and (4) enhanced scrutiny of citizens actions. Changes in these primary mechanisms are hypothesized to affect other secondary mechanisms: better maintenance of infrastructure (repair leaks, hire a half-time or plumber availability), better management procedures (better pricing, better financial management, more transparency) and fewer violations of household water use restrictions (informal connections, water used as input in businesses). The better management procedures could directly affect water consumption by increasing prices to maximum permissible increasing-block levels, or it could increase resources by improving financial management, which could lead to more investment in maintenance and infrastructure. Better maintenance of infrastructure could improve water quality and reduce water waste, which could reduce water pumping, and improve cost-effectiveness of CBWMO efforts to deliver water. Fewer violations of water use restrictions could improve water quality, reduce water consumption and increase CBWMO income, which in turn could increase investment in the water system. The two main outcome variables are electricity expenditures from groundwater pumping and water quality. Six secondary variables capture mechanisms: (i) degree of conservation pricing, (ii) institutional count metric, (iii) maintenance expenditures and repairs needed, (iv) number of citizens’ suggestions or requests in the last month, (v)scrutiny of the management committees’ activities and performance done by citizens, and (vi) community interest about the water system and the management performance. We also measure seven moderators: (1) number of CBWMO water connections; (2) the average tenure (in years) of the management committee members (question 18); (3) the gender composition of the management committee (question 18); (4) age of the management committee members (question 18) (5) CBWMO’s belief about the severity of water scarcity; (6) the participation in the 2015 CBWMO Management Training RCT, and (7) the power-off system of the pumps.

q17.value: We conducted an RCT with 161 CBWMOs: 80 in the treated group and 81 in the control group. We conduct workshops in the 80 treated CBWMOs to present the monitoring system and train monitors. Monitors are also incentivized to send weekly reports through the app and CBWMOs committee members are reminded to read the weekly reports. We collect baseline and endline surveys at the CBWMO level for almost all the variables, except for the electricity data that is provided by the energy companies and some process variables that are measured through the cellphone application. For the estimation of the main outcome variable electricity expenditures, we estimate a random effects model. See the description of all the other models in Section 5 in the Costa Rican Pre-Analysis Plan.

summary.value: Attached here is a preregistration for a follow-up to experiments not yet published. This version of the experiment has one small change from a previous version, that we have documented within this preregistration. We expect to replicate the findings from that version. This document outlines the research question, hypotheses, sampling plan, variables, design, and planned analyses. This experiment is currently being actively administered, however, none of the data has been looked at yet and we have outlined our stopping point criteria.

registration_responses.summary: Attached here is a preregistration for a follow-up to experiments not yet published. summary.value:
Analysis Plan

Planned analyses include four Welch independent t-tests, using experimental condition as the predictor. The outcome measure will be moral acceptability ratings. Consistent with Greene et al.’s (2009) analysis, the trolley and speedboat dilemmas will be analyzed separately. First, we will test differences in moral acceptability ratings for the trolley dilemmas with the following planned comparisons:

a) footbridge vs. footbridge pole, to assess the effect of physical contact. No statistically significant effect is predicted. 

b) a planned comparison of footbridge pole vs. footbridge switch, to assess the effect of personal force. It is expected that the mean moral acceptability ratings will be higher in the footbridge switch condition when compared to the footbridge pole condition. 

Second, we will conduct a similar set of planned tests on the speedboat dilemmas:

c) standard speedboat vs. speedboat oar, to assess the effect of physical contact. No 	statistically significant effect is predicted.

d) speedboat oar vs. speedboat accelerate, to assess the effect of personal force. It is expected that the mean moral acceptability ratings will be higher in the speedboat accelerate condition when compared to the speedboat oar condition.

Mean differences and 95% confidence intervals will be reported. Effect sizes will be calculated using cohen’s d. 

It is worth noting that the original study found no statistically significant effect of physical contact. We are conducting a similar test because it matches the planned comparisons in the replication target. However, non-significant p-values cannot endorse the null, but can only fail to reject it.  Thus, results for tests a) and c) are predicted to be inconclusive, consistent with Greene et al. (2009). 

Additional analyses on these data may be conducted in an exploratory fashion. Any such analyses will be clearly delineated as exploratory. 

Power Analysis

We will require a minimum of 64 participants per condition (192 participants total) to detect an effect size of d = .50, assuming a two-tailed alpha of .05 and 80% power. More data than this is desirable but may be restricted due to feasibility concerns, as these data are being collected as part of an honors thesis, and thus we have a short time window for data collection. Data collection will take place between September 2019 and February 2020. Data collection will continue until February 23th, 2020.  Thus, our planned sample size is a minimum of 192, but may be larger than this depending on how many participants can be collected before the stop date.

Second, we will conduct a similar set of planned tests on the speedboat dilemmas:

c) standard speedboat vs. speedboat oar, to assess the effect of physical contact. No 	statistically significant effect is predicted.

Additional analyses on these data may be conducted in an exploratory fashion. Any such analyses will be clearly delineated as exploratory.

We will require a minimum of 64 participants per condition (192 participants total) to detect an effect size of d = .50, assuming a two-tailed alpha of .05 and 80% power. More data than this is desirable but may be restricted due to feasibility concerns, as these data are being collected as part of an honors thesis, and thus we have a short time window for data collection. summary.value:
Study 3 rationale; additions to Studies 1 and 2. 
We will build on Studies 1 and 2 by investigating participants’ spontaneous production of generic statements. Study 1 and 2 demonstrated that participants do not evaluate generic statements in a monolithic way but rather in a context-specific way. That is, generics referencing structural factors like discrimination are evaluated differently from generics referencing stereotyped traits, values, and preferences. This raises questions about what kinds of generic statements White and Black participants spontaneously use in their descriptions of the world. Do White and Black participants ever use generic statements? If so, what kind, and when? Additionally, individual variation in racist beliefs and attitudes strongly predicted evaluations of generic statements – do they predict production of generic statements? 
Unlike Studies 1 and 2 which were very explicit in their connection to race, the experimental portion of this study was designed to reduce the salience of race. Specifically, the experiment portion will include no generic statements about race nor category labels and will include filler trials that are not race related. 
Hypotheses. 
1.	We predict that generic statements referencing structural factors will outnumber generic statements referencing stereotypes traits, values, and preferences.   

2.	We predict that racism will predict fewer structural generics and more stereotyped generics (if they are produced often enough to measure this relationship).

3.	 We expected Black participants to produce more generics referencing structural factors than White participants. Based on Study 2 though, we did not expect Black and White participants to differ in their production of generics referencing stereotypes (especially since we focused on stories evoking ‘positive’ stereotypes here). 
Sample size. 
We selected the same sample size as Study 1 based on the same rationale: 100 participants per condition (generics about structural properties, generics about stereotypes) per race (Black, White), to give us 95% power to detect medium effect sizes (d = .50). 
Design and Procedure.
Participants will read 4 short descriptions of individuals (2 experimental, 2 filler) that either invoke structural factors (Structural condition) or stereotyped traits (Stereotype condition) – between-subject. Participants will be asked to write 3-4 sentences in response to the descriptions. We can then code the statements for genericity and their content. Participants then answered a battery of questions assessing racial bias: Symbolic racism, White-Black social dominance, and feeling thermometers. 
Of the four descriptions, 2 were experimental and 2 were filler. The experimental trials involved a Black individual experiencing discrimination (Structural condition) or exhibiting a stereotyped trait (Stereotype condition), and thus provided the opportunity for participants to use race-related generic language. The other 2 trials included broadly similar content but involved non-Black individuals involved in events that did not evoke race-related structural factors or stereotypes. 
Descriptions.
Structural (experimental). 

…
This man's name is Peter. 

 

Peter received a text from his boss saying that his natural hair was unprofessional. He confronted his employer, who apologized. The following week he took a sick day; his boss called and told him he was being let go due to his poor work ethic. 
…

This woman's name is Nadya.

 

Nadya went to an expensive clothing store. The clerk followed her and assumed she did not belong. The clerk kept asking if she needed help and kept closely watching her when she said no. 
Structural (filler: stories involve characters being treated badly in a non-structural non-race-related way).

…

This woman's name is Erica.

 
 
Erica went to the grocery store last week. While she was trying to pick out spinach, an older woman walked in front of her and started looking for spinach herself. Erica ended up not being able to find spinach because the older woman blocked her completely. 

…

This man's name is Nathan.

 

Last night Nathan was at a night club. When he asked a woman at the club to dance, she laughed in his face and said "Obviously I wouldn't dance with you?" The experience made him feel embarrassed so he left earlier than anticipated. 


 
Stereotypes (experimental; stereotypes: athleticism and musicality/singing ability). 
This man's name is Peter. 

 

Peter recently tried out for his college track team. He had never run competitively before but he performed better than some of the men already on the team. The coach said he was a natural. He even went to the state tournament that season and placed in the top three.

…
This woman's name is Nadya.

 

 
Nadya started college last semester and started going to a cappella groups. She had been singing for years in church groups in her neighborhood. Due to her training and passion for singing, she had a powerful voice. She became one of the lead singers in the group and was often asked to perform solos.

…









Structural (filler: stories involve characters being good at something they started at college).

This man's name is Nathan.

 

Nathan always had friends who skateboarded but he never tried himself. This past semester he started skateboarding with them. He had trouble at first but quickly became proficient. Now it's his favorite hobby and posts videos on YouTube where he teaches other people how to do advanced tricks.

…

This woman's name is Erica.

 
 
Erica is in her second year of college. She switched majors to study Classics. She has been doing a lot better in school now because she feels passionate about the material. Now she's learning Ancient Greek so she can read ancient texts in their original language.

…
 
Prompt:
Please write 3-4 sentences about the individual and event mentioned above in your own words. [This prompt was given after each story; participants had a text box provided to write in].
Coding scheme.

A statement is defined as an independent clause whether embedded in a larger complex sentence or not: e.g., “I drink green tea, but they drink coffee” would count as two statements. We will only code and analyze statements produced in response to the 2 experimental trials. 

1.	The DV of interest is categorical generic statements produced about Black people. Our first pass in coding is whether a generic reference racial category. We will code whether the statements reference Black people (“Black people”, “Blacks”, “Black men”, “Black women”, “African-Americans”, etc.) or White people (“White people”, “Whites”, “White men”, “White women”, “European-Americans”, “Caucasians”, etc.). Given the stimuli, it is unlikely there will be generics about other racial categories. 

2.	Second, we will code whether the categorical statements are generic or some other form: 

A.	Categorical generics.

Generic statements were identified by two principles: First, the statement assigned a property to the entire category by taking the form of a base plural (“Black people”), plural pronoun (“they”), definite plural (“the Blacks”), or indefinite singular (“a Black person”). Second, the property expresses a permanent / stable / habitual / indefinite state rather than an impermanent / transient / temporary / definite state. “She drinks green tea” expresses an indefinite state, whereas “She is drinking green tea” expressed a transient state. 


B.	Belief statements about the category. 

We suspected participants might write in statements like “She thought the Black woman was robbing the store.” We counted these separately since the category-relevant statement is attributed to someone’s beliefs. In the case of a statement like “White people think Black people are criminals,” we would count it as both a generic (“White people think…” and a belief statement. Presumably we will count these statements primarily as structural. For example, “Black people are treated with suspicion” is the complement of “People think Black people are suspicious.” 

C.	Category-based explanations.

Another common statement type might be statements like “She was treated suspiciously because she’s Black” or “He’s good at running because he’s Black.” Explanations that contained generics will be counted as generics too: “She sings well because Black people are good at singing.” 

D.	Quantified generalizations. 

“Most White people…” “Many Black people…” “Some African Americans…”

E.	Specifics with category labels. 

“This Black woman…” “An African American man joined the track team”

F.	Other

3.	Finally, we will code whether the category-related statements reference:

A.	Structural factors:  e.g., Black people face workplace discrimination; White people treat Black people with suspicion; Black people have less power than White people).

B.	Stereotyped values, traits, and preferences: e.g., “Black people are athletic”, “Black people don’t value hard work”

C.	Other: “White people have straight hair.”


Questions about participants attitudes
1.	Symbolic racism scale, brief. 
a.	Q1. Irish, Italian, Jewish, and many other minorities overcame prejudice and worked their way up. Black people should do the same. Black people are demanding too much from the rest of society.
b.	Q2. Black people are demanding too much from the rest of society.
c.	Q3. Discrimination against Black people is no longer a problem in the United States.
2.	Social dominance orientation about White/Black 
a.	If Black people stayed in their place, we would have fewer problems.
b.	It is okay if White people have more of a chance in today’s society than Black people.
c.	Black people are simply inferior to White people.
d.	People should be given an equal chance in life regardless of whether they are Black or White. (Reverse-coded)
e.	We should do what we can to equalize conditions between Black and White people. (Reverse-coded)
f.	It would be good if Black and White people could be equal. (Reverse-coded)
Demographics
1.	Political orientation: Very Conservative. Conservative. Moderate. Liberal. Very Liberal.
2.	Gender: Man. Woman. Genderqueer. Other. Prefer not to answer.
3.	Race: White, Black, Other (we are specifically recruiting White and Black participants from Turk Prime panels, so all participants should be White or Black). 

Analyses. 
The primary dependent variables of interest are how many stereotype-referencing generics participants produced about Black people and how many structural-referencing generics participants produced about Black people. Both of these variables are non-negative integers. They will likely be rare (we expect maybe ~15% of statements to be generic). To analyze this data, we will use Poisson multi-level regressions. 
These models also provide the possibility of modelling the data as a rate adding an offset term. We will add an offset term for the total number of statements participants produced, as each additional statement provides more opportunities for a statement to be generic or not. 
Between subject, participants are assigned either to a condition with excerpts that prompt structural issues or a condition with excerpts that prompt stereotyped traits. Each of these conditions should have their own effect, such that structural generics are more likely when structural issues are prompted. However, the idea is that (1) participants should be more likely to describe structural issues in generic terms than stereotyped traits, (2) participants’ racism should moderate their propensity to produce generic statements in the face of those prompts (up-regulating generics about stereotyped properties and down-regulating generics about structural issues). Therefore, the analysis will still primarily be within-subject looking at the type of generics participants produce.  
Primary analyses.
Analysis 1: 
First, we will look at which type of generics are produced more often. We will use a multi-level model on the number of generics by type (structural vs. stereotyped) with an offset term for total statements produced. We hypothesize that structural statements will be produced more often that stereotyped statements. 
1.	glmer(Generics ~ Type+ offset(LogTotal) +(1|Par), family="poisson", data=data.frame)
Analysis 2:
Second, we will report whether the conditions effect the type of generics participants produce. We expected structural generics to be especially likely in the structural condition. 
2.	glmer(Generics ~ Type * Condition + offset(LogTotal) +(1|Par), …
Analysis 3: 
Third, we will report a model examining the effect of racism. We expected a significant interaction. Racism should lead to higher incidence of stereotyped generics and a lower incidence of structural generics. 
3.	glmer(Generics ~ Type * Racism + offset(LogTotal) +(1|Par), …
Analysis 4: 
Fourth, we will report a model examining participant race. We expected Black participants to produce more structural generics than White participants. 
4.	glmer(Generics ~ Type * Participant_Race + offset(LogTotal) +(1|Par), …
Additional Considerations
1.	It will be worth reporting how often generic statements are produced about White people. We made no specific predictions about generics about White people. In general, generic statements about White people may blur the lines: “White people treat Black people with suspicion”, “White people are racist,” “White people dislike Black people,” and “White people are evil” vary from mostly structural to mostly stereotypical but it is unclear exactly what the boundary is between the two. And presumably generic statements about White people will not show the same relationships participant race and anti-Black racism as generic statements about Black people. However, collapsing across the type of generic statements produced, it is still worth asking:
a.	Do Black participants produce generic statements about White people more often than White people?
b.	Do participants in general produce more or less generic statements about White people than Black people?
c.	Does (anti-Black) racism predict less generics about White people? 

2.	It will be worth analyzing other types of category-related statements. In particular, we suspected that category-based explanations might be produced frequently: e.g., “She was followed because she’s Black.” Do category-related statements show the same pattern as generic statements? Theoretically, category-based explanations and generics should be cognitively inter-related. Thus, we predict that category-based explanations will show the same pattern of results as generic statements.

summary.value:
Temporal Explanations Registration (TX1)

Explanations can help resolve conflicts in information (Khemlani, 2018). Some explanations are non-causal in nature, but the vast majority of contemporary research into explanatory reasoning concerns causal explanations. For instance, a causal explanation for why, e.g., Ria was late to a meeting is that his car broke down. Previous studies show that people spontaneously generate causal explanations when they detect that a set of premises is inconsistent (Khemlani & Johnson-Laird, 2011). In this study, we test whether people spontaneously produce non-causal, temporal explanations when provided with an inconsistent set of premises. Temporal explanations are explanations that appeal to events and their relations to one another in time. A temporal explanation for why Ria was late to work would be, e.g., that the meeting was rescheduled -- and so Ria was not, in fact, late. The explanation appeals to temporal, not causal relations, to resolve conflicts.

This is a first exploratory experiment attempting to elicit temporal explanations from participants. Using materials from our previous work (Reasoning about durations), we have maintained the independent variables of problem type (one model vs. multiple models) and consistency (consistent vs. inconsistent). The models referenced in problem type refer to possible iconic mental models of the temporal relations.  If the sunrise was before the commute and the podcast was during the commute, the only possible unspecified relation is the sunrise was before the podcast.  If instead we know that the podcast is during the commute and the sunrise was before the podcast, there are two possible relations: either the sunrise was before the commute or the sunrise was during the commute (before the podcast started). In this experiment, participants are told 2 facts: "1. The sunrise happened before the commute. 2. The podcast was during the commute." Then they are told a new fact: "You discover the following fact: 3. The podcast happened before the sunrise." And they are asked an open-response question: "What, if anything, follows?" In this case, it is inconsistent for the podcast to have happened before the sunrise when it happened during the commute that is after the sunrise.  Participants who notice the temporal conflict may state that one of the facts is simply wrong or they could generate an explanation: There were two podcasts. The podcast happened during the sunrise, too. The podcast was put on pause during the sunrise. 

Half of the 16 problems will be inconsistent and it is our prediction that there will be more explanations, and in particular temporal explanations, for the inconsistent problems than for the consistent problems. The responses will be coded for 1. explanation given and 2. type of explanation (with the key one being temporal or something else).  We will use non-parametric tests of the factors (problem type, consistency, their interaction) individually, an omnibus ANOVA with appropriate post-hoc contrasts, and a linear mixed effect regression model with estimated marginal means for the post-hoc contrasts.

We have collected 50 participants via Amazon Mechanical Turk with a payment of $2.00. This registration was written before the data was finished being collected and analyzed but languished as a draft until now.

registration_responses.summary:
Temporal Explanations Registration (TX1)

Explanations can help resolve conflicts in information (Khemlani, 2018). Some explanations are non-causal in nature, but the vast majority of contemporary research into explanatory reasoning concerns causal explanations. For instance, a causal explanation for why, e.g., Ria was late to a meeting is that his car broke down. Previous studies show that people spontaneously generate causal explanations when they detect that a set of premises is inconsistent (Khemlani & Johnson-Laird, 2011). In this study, we test whether people spontaneously produce non-causal, temporal explanations when provided with an inconsistent set of premises. Temporal explanations are explanations that appeal to events and their relations to one another in time. A temporal explanation for why Ria was late to work would be, e.g., that the meeting was rescheduled -- and so Ria was not, in fact, late. The explanation appeals to temporal, not causal relations, to resolve conflicts.

This is a first exploratory experiment attempting to elicit temporal explanations from participants. Using materials from our previous work (Reasoning about durations), we have maintained the independent variables of problem type (one model vs. multiple models) and consistency (consistent vs. inconsistent). The models referenced in problem type refer to possible iconic mental models of the temporal relations.  If the sunrise was before the commute and the podcast was during the commute, the only possible unspecified relation is the sunrise was before the podcast.  If instead we know that the podcast is during the commute and the sunrise was before the podcast, there are two possible relations: either the sunrise was before the commute or the sunrise was during the commute (before the podcast started). In this experiment, participants are told 2 facts: "1. The sunrise happened before the commute. 2. The podcast was during the commute." Then they are told a new fact: "You discover the following fact: 3. The podcast happened before the sunrise." And they are asked an open-response question: "What, if anything, follows?" In this case, it is inconsistent for the podcast to have happened before the sunrise when it happened during the commute that is after the sunrise.  Participants who notice the temporal conflict may state that one of the facts is simply wrong or they could generate an explanation: There were two podcasts. The podcast happened during the sunrise, too. The podcast was put on pause during the sunrise. 

Half of the 16 problems will be inconsistent and it is our prediction that there will be more explanations, and in particular temporal explanations, for the inconsistent problems than for the consistent problems. The responses will be coded for 1. explanation given and 2. type of explanation (with the key one being temporal or something else).  We will use non-parametric tests of the factors (problem type, consistency, their interaction) individually, an omnibus ANOVA with appropriate post-hoc contrasts, and a linear mixed effect regression model with estimated marginal means for the post-hoc contrasts.

We have collected 50 participants via Amazon Mechanical Turk with a payment of $2.00. This registration was written before the data was finished being collected and analyzed but languished as a draft until now.
